newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish banks wary of bourse merger scheme.
newsitem.headline: Swedish banks wary of bourse merger scheme.

text.p: Swedish banks holding a major stake in the Stockholm Stock Exchange believe that plans to merge the bourse and the OM futures and options exchange could concentrate too much power in the hands of a few owners.

Business daily Dagens Industri said that the two exchanges were working on a proposal that the OM group, which includes a futures and derivatives exchange, an energy bourse and systems development and consultancy units, would buy the stock exchange.
The merged exchanges would then trade as a unit of the bourse-listed OM group, where the powerful Wallenberg family interests constitute the largest bloc of shareholders.

"It is definitely wrong to let the new marketplace be owned by a bourse-listed company. Furthermore we don't want the market to get one or a few dominant owners," Nordbanken Markets chief Anders Nyren told the Dagens Nyheter daily.
Nordbanken, Handelsbanken, Foreningsbanken and Swedbank between them hold a 20 percent stake in the Stockholm Stock Exchange, the papers said.

The OM group, 20.1 percent owned by the Wallenberg holding company Investor, owns 20.7 percent of the stock exchange. Investor owns another 6.7 percent directly and Wallenberg-associated firms like S-E-Banken hold 15.1 percent.
"It would be better if the parent company were unlisted and had broad ownership," Bjorn C.Andersen, deputy Handelsbanken chief and stock exchange board-member told Dagens Industri.
"This is primarily about public confidence. We must ensure that the new bourse company cannot suddenly be bought by a new owner," he said.
Swedbank's Hakan Kallaker said that the banks' opposition was not directed at the Wallenbergs in particular but to the principle of any group dominating management of a combined securities market.
"The question of owner concentration must be resolved, in that context it makes no difference if it is a Wallenberg company or someone else who is the dominant owner," he told Dagens Industri.
